column4: Sandvik agrees to sell 70% of Drilling and Completions
column5: STOCKHOLM (Reuters) - Metal-cutting tools maker Sandvik SAND.ST has agreed to sell 70% of its drilling and completions business for 900 million crowns ($92.8 mln) in line with its strategy to focus on core operations.
column6: The Swedish group said on Monday it would sell the part of Sandvik Drilling and Completions that makes products for the oil and gas industry to private equity firm Blue Water Energy and Nixon Energy Investments.
column7: It said it would book a 3.9 billion crown goodwill writedown related to the divestment in the fourth quarter and aimed to finalize the deal in the first quarter of 2020.
column8: Sandvik said last year it was evaluating options for the business, which it bought in 2014 for $740 million and was part of its mining and rock technology unit.
column9: Sandvik, which last week appointed a new CEO, will keep the remaining 30% of Drilling and Completions which makes products for the mining industry.
column10: The group, which has struggled historically to safeguard profitability during cyclical downturns, has in recent years sold a string of businesses it considers to be outside its core operations.

column5: (Reuters) - Oilfield services company Precision Drilling's PD.TO loss narrowed for the third-quarter, helped by higher drilling activity across North America, the Canadian company reported on Thursday.
column6: Net loss narrowed to C$3.5 million ($2.68 million), or 1 Canadian cent per share, from C$30.6 million, or 10 Canadian cents a share, a year earlier.
column7: Revenue fell about 2% to C$376 million.

column4: Ensign Energy tender gets over 50 percent of Trinidad shares, Precision ends bid
column5: (Reuters) - Canada's oilfield services provider Ensign Energy Services Inc ESI.TO said on Tuesday about 56 percent of Trinidad Drilling Ltd's TDG.TO shares have been tendered in its hostile offer, with rival bidder Precision Drilling Corp PD.TO walking away.
column6: Precision and Trinidad’s shares both closed up more than 2.5 percent, while Ensign ended down 8.8 percent.
column7: Ensign said the tendered shares helped meet the statutory minimum condition for its C$947-million hostile offer. The company now owned 66.18 percent of Trinidad shares, including stock in the company it previously owned.
column8: Precision said on Tuesday it was awaiting payment of the termination fee of $20,000,000, based on its agreement with Trinidad.
column9: The rival bids underscored how oilfield service providers are looking to cushion the impact of Canadian oil producers tapping the brakes on spending, as pipeline bottlenecks result in wide discounts for Western Canada Select heavy crude to U.S. benchmark crude CLc1.
column10: Ensign decided to launch the bid in August after Trinidad completed a strategic review it began in February, while North American drilling contractor Precision in October offered a deal valued at C$1.03 billion.
column11: Trinidad’s board had rejected the C$1.68 per share all-cash bid from Ensign and instead urged shareholders to accept an all-stock offer from Precision.

column4: Ensign Energy says over 50 pct of Trinidad shares tendered in hostile bid
column5: Nov 27 (Reuters) - Canada’s oilfield services provider Ensign Energy Services Inc said on Tuesday about 56 percent of Trinidad Drilling Ltd’s shares have been tendered to its hostile bid, giving the company an upper hand over Precision Drilling Corp’s rival offer.
column6: The company said this helped meet the statutory minimum condition for its offer of C$947 million. The company now owned 66.18 percent of issued and outstanding Trinidad shares, including the 26,863,239 shares of Trinidad it already owned.
column7: Ensign decided to launch the hostile bid for Trinidad in August after the target company completed a strategic review it began in February, while North American drilling contractor Precision offered a deal valued at C$1.03 billion in October.
column8: Precision, which last week asked Trinidad shareholders to reject Ensign’s offer, was not immediately available for comment.

column4: Precision Drilling trumps Ensign bid for peer Trinidad
column5: (Reuters) - North American drilling contractor Precision Drilling Corp PD.TO on Friday said it would buy Trinidad Drilling Ltd TDG.TO in a deal valued at C$1.03 billion ($796 million), trumping a hostile bid from rival Ensign Energy Services ESI.TO.
column6: The acquisition, which has an enterprise value of about C$4 billion, makes Precision the third-largest driller in the United States with more than 200 active rigs and 322 rigs in total, said the companies, both based in the Canadian province of Alberta.
column7: “We’ll have strong coverage in other U.S. shale plays and in the Permian,” said Precision Chief Financial Officer Carey Ford on a call with analysts.
column8: Precision expects the deal, which was unanimously approved by Trinidad’s board, to save it more than C$30 million per year.
column9: Trinidad’s board in August rejected a C$1.68 per share all-cash bid from Ensign and instead urged shareholders to accept an all-stock offer from Precision. The all-stock bid, C$1.98 per share based on the bidder’s closing price on Thursday, represented a 7.6 percent premium to Trinidad’s closing price on that day.
column10: Oil producers in Alberta face pipeline bottlenecks that result in very big price discounts for Western Canada Select heavy crude SHRWCSMc2 to U.S. benchmark crude CLc1.
column11: Those differentials have left Canadian oil-producing companies trailing their U.S. peers and kept them cautious about spending. Trinidad has lost money since 2015.
column12: “[It’s] positive to see continued consolidation in the land rig space,” analysts at Capital One Securities Inc wrote in a note on Friday.
column13: The deal comes a few months after Independence Contract Drilling and Sidewinder Drilling merged their businesses, and Weatherford International WFT.N sold a portion of its land rigs in the Middle East to ADES International.
column14: Excluding debt, the deal is valued at C$551 million and is expected to close in late-2018.
column15: Shares of Trinidad were up 6 percent at C$1.95 on the Toronto Stock Exchange, while Precision’s shares were down about 1.6 percent and Ensign’s were off nearly 7 percent in afternoon trading on Friday.

column4: Precision Drilling to buy Trinidad Drilling in C$1.03 bln deal
column5: Oct 5 (Reuters) - Canadian rig contractor Precision Drilling Corp said on Friday it would buy smaller rival Trinidad Drilling Limited in a deal valued at C$1.03 billion ($796 million).
column6: Precision said it has agreed to buy all shares of Trinidad on the basis of 0.445 common shares of Precision for each outstanding Trinidad share. ($1 = 1.2930 Canadian dollars) (Reporting by John Benny in Bengaluru; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)

column4: Precision Drilling posts bigger-than-expected quarterly loss
column5: (Reuters) - Precision Drilling Corp PD.TOPDS.N reported a bigger-than-expected quarterly loss on Thursday as increased spending at the Canadian oilfield services company overshadowed higher day rates of its U.S. rigs.
column6: Expenditure on expansion more than tripled to C$15.8 million, while maintenance spending was four times higher than a year ago at C$13.1 million.
column7: “During the quarter, we activated eight rigs in the U.S. and currently have 78 rigs running with visibility for four to six additional activations in the coming weeks,” Chief Executive Kevin Neveu said in a statement. nGNXp1C5l
column8: Revenue from rig utilization per day rose 10 percent to $21,795 in the United States while falling marginally to C$22,072 in Canada.
column9: Oil producers from Western Canada have been hurt by wider discounts of the region’s heavy oil as transportation bottlenecks make it harder to send the crude to U.S. refineries.
column10: Net loss widened to C$47.2 million ($36.20 million), or 16 Canadian cents per share, in the second quarter ended June 30, from C$36.1 million, or 12 Canadian cents per share, a year earlier.
column11: Analysts had on average estimated a loss of 14 Canadian cents, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column12: Revenue rose 13.7 percent to C$330.72 million.

column4: Precision Drilling loss widens on higher expenses
column5: July 26 (Reuters) - Precision Drilling Corp reported a bigger quarterly loss on Thursday as the Canadian oilfield services company spent more on maintenance and expansion.
column6: Net loss widened to C$47.2 million ($36.20 million), or 16 Canadian cents per share, in the second quarter ended June 30, from C$36.1 million, or 12 Canadian cents per share, a year earlier.
column7: Revenue rose 13.7 percent to C$330.72 million. ($1 = 1.3039 Canadian dollars) (Reporting by Karan Nagarkatti in Bengaluru Editing by Supriya Kurane)

column4: CANADA STOCKS-TSX edges higher, led by materials; Shopify slides
column5: May 1 (Reuters) - * The Toronto Stock Exchange’s S&P/TSX composite index rose 11.05 points, or 0.07 percent, to 15,618.93
column6: * The materials group, which includes precious and base metals miners and fertilizer companies, added 0.5 percent
column7: * The industrials group fell 0.8 percent as railroad shares lost ground
column8: * Leading the index were Detour Gold Corp, up 9.5 percent, Colliers International Group Inc, up 7.8 percent, and Cameco Corp, higher by 6.1 percent
column9: * Lagging shares were Secure Energy Services Inc , down 5.1 percent, Shopify Inc, down 4.9 percent, and Precision Drilling Corp, lower by 4.6 percent
column10: * Shares of Shopify fell after the company reported a slower first quarter growth rate
column11: * On the TSX 136 issues advanced and 107 declined as a 1.3-to-1 ratio favored advancers. There were 7 new highs and 1 new lows, with total volume of 166.3 million shares
column12: * The most heavily traded shares by volume were Encana Corp , Baytex Energy Corp and Bombardier Inc
column13: * The TSX’s energy group fell 0.69 points, or 0.35 percent, while the financials sector climbed 0.20 points, or 0.07 percent
column14: * West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell $1.11 to $67.46 a barrel
column15: * The TSX is off 3.6 percent for the year (Editing by Alden Bentley)

column4: Precision Drilling sees smaller loss, ups 2018 capex
column5: (Reuters) - Canadian rig contractor Precision Drilling Corp PD.TO, PDS.N reported a smaller-than-expected loss on Thursday as its U.S. clients deployed more of the company's rigs to take advantage of rising oil prices. Precision's number of rigs at work in the United States rose by 36 percent to 64 on average during the first quarter.
column6: “As a result of increased demand in our U.S. operations, we are increasing our projected capital spending by C$22 million,” Chief Executive Kevin Neveu said, adding that about half of that would be used to expand and upgrade the drilling fleet.
column7: Its Canadian count fell to 72 active rigs on average from 76 a year ago as transport bottlenecks and high production costs saw a number of oil majors withdraw from the country.
column8: Revenue from rig utilization per day was up 3.8 percent to C$22,209 in Canada, while it rose marginally to $20,603 in the U.S.
column9: Excluding items, the company lost 6 Canadian cents per share. Analysts on average had expected Precision to lose 7 Canadian cents, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column10: Net loss narrowed to C$18.1 million ($14.09 million), or 6 Canadian cents per share, in the first quarter ended Mar. 31, from net loss of C$22.6 million ($17.61 million), or 8 Canadian cents per share, a year earlier.
column11: Revenue rose to C$401 million from C$368.7 million.

column4: BRIEF-Precision Drilling Corp Reports Q1 Loss Per Share C$0.06
column6: * ORATION ANNOUNCES 2018 FIRST QUARTER UNAUDITED FINANCIAL RESULTS
column7: * Q1 REVENUE C$401 MILLION VERSUS I/B/E/S VIEW C$390.1 MILLION
column8: * Q1 EARNINGS PER SHARE VIEW C$-0.07 -- THOMSON REUTERS I/B/E/S
column9: * RESTATED A DEBT REDUCTION TARGET OF $300 MILLION TO $500 MILLION OVER NEXT THREE TO FOUR YEARS

column5: April 26 (Reuters) - Canadian rig contractor Precision Drilling Corp on Thursday reported a smaller first-quarter loss, helped by greater U.S demand and higher day rates for the company’s rigs.
column6: Net loss narrowed to C$18.1 million, or 6 Canadian cents per share, in the quarter ended Mar. 31, from net loss of C$22.6 million, or 8 Canadian cents per share, a year earlier.
column7: Revenue rose to C$401 million from C$368.7 million. (Reporting by Karan Nagarkatti in Bengaluru; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)
